access.description: The registered URL is a HubSpot-hosted page that returns HTTP 200 directly via curl with a standard User-Agent. The page contains static HTML with embedded screenshots — no JavaScript rendering required. The URL includes a HubSpot preview parameter (hs_preview=FslteQVE-143661230087), but the page also works at its canonical URL without the preview parameter. Cloudflare is present but does not block access. No accordion expansion, tab navigation, or login required.

products.name: ECP

product_context.description: ECP is a specialty, vertically-integrated EHR and operational management platform built specifically for the senior living and long-term care (LTC) industry — particularly assisted living communities, independent living, memory care, I/DD programs, and group homes. It is NOT a general-purpose hospital or ambulatory EHR. The product consists of five integrated modules: eMAR (electronic medication administration with 600+ pharmacy integrations), EHR and Care Plans (assessments, care plans, task management, incident reporting, compliance automation), Billing (charge capture, payment processing, invoices, GL export), CRM (lead management, pipeline tracking), and Move-Ins (admissions workflow, digital document management). ECP serves 8,000+ communities with 120,000+ daily users across all 50 states. The certified module is the entire ECP platform, but the certification scope is extremely minimal — only (b)(10) EHI export, (d)(12)/(d)(13) authentication, and (g)(4)/(g)(5) quality/accessibility. No clinical criteria (a)(1)-(a)(14), no patient portal (e)(1), and no FHIR API (g)(7)-(g)(10) are certified, despite the product having clinical EHR capabilities.

export_approach.description: ECP's EHI export is a manual, report-based, user-driven process — not a database dump, not FHIR, not C-CDA. Users navigate the ECP UI to generate reports at three levels (company-wide via Executive Menu, location-level via Admin Menu, and resident-level via individual resident tiles), select which fields to include, and export results to Excel or PDF. There is no single 'export all EHI' button. Each data category (demographics, diagnoses, medications, vitals, etc.) requires navigating to a separate report and exporting it individually. For at least some reports (the Report Generator), users must manually select which fields to include — creating risk of incomplete exports if fields are not all selected. This is the least automated export approach possible: it pushes all the burden of completeness onto the end user, who must know which reports exist, navigate to each one, select appropriate fields, and export them one at a time.

documentation_quality.description: The documentation is a single instructional web page with 11 annotated screenshots showing how to navigate the ECP UI to export data. It is essentially a user guide — 'click here, then click here, then click export.' There is no data dictionary, no schema documentation, no field definitions, no table listings, and no export format specifications. The screenshots reveal some data categories (report names visible in the UI) and some field names (visible in the field selection UI), but the documentation makes no attempt to enumerate all exportable data, describe data types, or document relationships between data elements. The Report Generator screenshot is cut off, so the full list of available report types is not even visible. This is among the thinnest EHI export documentation we have encountered.

ehi_coverage.overall_assessment: The documentation is so thin that it's difficult to assess coverage with confidence. Based on the report names and field names visible in the screenshots, ECP appears to offer export of core clinical data categories relevant to long-term care (diagnoses, medications/MAR, vitals, assessments, care plans, incidents/falls). However, the export requires manual navigation to many separate reports with manual field selection, and there are significant gaps. The Billing module (charges, payments, invoices) is a core product feature but billing data is barely represented in the export documentation beyond 'Invoices from ECP' and 'Rent Roll' at the Admin level. CRM and Move-Ins module data (leads, family contacts, admissions documents, signed forms) does not appear at all. There is no evidence of messaging or communication data export. The Audit Log is present, which is a positive finding. Overall, the export appears to cover basic LTC clinical data but likely omits significant portions of what the broader ECP platform stores — particularly billing detail, CRM data, admissions documents, and any communication records.

clinical.evidence: Multiple clinical report types visible: Resident Diagnoses, Medication History (MAR), Med Pass History, Vitals History, Assessments On File, Care History (TAR), Care Provided History, Observation History, Incident Reports, Fall Reports, Vaccinations & Screenings, Infections Report, Symptoms Report, Level of Care Change Report, Risk Analysis Tool. Resident record also shows Face Sheet, Physician Order Sheet, and Life Story tabs. Resident File Information report shows demographic fields including Medicare/Medicaid numbers, Code Status, Hospital Preference, and Health Care Power of Attorney.

secure_messages.evidence: No messaging, inbox, communication, chat, or correspondence reports or fields visible in any of the documentation screenshots. ECP does not have a patient portal (no (e)(1) certification). The Move-Ins module has family-facing digital document tools and the CRM has email integration, but no export mechanism for communications is documented.

billing_financial.evidence: Partially present. 'Invoices from ECP' and 'Rent Roll' appear in Administration > Reports. 'Petty Cash Report' and 'Service Summary Report' appear in Executive Administration. However, the full Billing module (charge capture, payment processing, payment history, chargebacks, disputes, NSFs, GL export data) is a core product feature and the export documentation does not clearly show how detailed billing line items, payment records, or financial transaction history are exported. The gap between the product's billing capabilities and what's shown in the export documentation is concerning.

insurance_coverage.evidence: The Resident File Information report includes Medicare and Medicaid number fields, but no insurance plan details, eligibility information, authorization data, or coverage details are visible. For a long-term care setting, this would include Medicaid/Medicare coverage details, long-term care insurance information, and level-of-care authorization data.

appointments_scheduling.evidence: Not applicable in the traditional sense — long-term care facilities don't have appointment scheduling like ambulatory settings. Residency Start/End dates serve as admission/discharge records and are present in the Resident File Information report. Level of Care Change Report serves as a care transition record. 'Apartment Census' and 'Resident Status Census' provide occupancy-level data.

documents_images.evidence: No document management, scanned documents, uploaded files, or image export visible in any documentation. The Move-Ins module mentions families can 'upload files' and both CRM and Move-Ins have 'digital signatures,' but no export mechanism for these documents is shown in the EHI export documentation.

audit_trails.evidence: 'Audit Log' report is visible in the Administration > Reports tab. This is a positive finding — many vendors don't include audit data in their export. However, no details are provided about what the audit log contains (who accessed records, what was changed, timestamps, etc.).

issues: No data dictionary or schema documentation — the EHI export documentation is just a user guide with screenshots showing how to click through the UI.
Manual, report-by-report export with no single 'export all EHI' button. Users must navigate to multiple reports and export each separately, creating significant risk of missing data categories.
User must manually select which fields to include in reports via the Report Generator. If all fields are not selected, data is silently omitted from the export.
PDF is offered as an export format alongside Excel. PDF is not machine-readable and should not be the primary export format for EHI data.
Report Generator Exec screenshot is cut off — the full list of available report types is not visible in the documentation.
Significant billing gap: ECP has a full Billing module (charges, payments, invoices, GL export) but the export documentation shows minimal billing reports (just 'Invoices from ECP' and 'Rent Roll').
CRM and Move-Ins module data (leads, family contacts, admissions documents, signed forms) does not appear in the export documentation at all.
No documentation of what fields are available in each report type (except Resident File Information, which is partially visible in a screenshot).
Registered URL contains HubSpot preview parameter, suggesting the page may have been registered while in draft mode.
Minimal ONC certification scope — only (b)(10), (d)(12), (d)(13), (g)(4), (g)(5). No clinical criteria certified despite the product being a clinical EHR.
products.summary: ECP provides the thinnest possible EHI export documentation — a single web page with screenshots showing how to click through the UI to generate and export reports. There is no data dictionary, no field definitions, and no bulk export mechanism. The export requires users to manually navigate to multiple separate reports, select fields, and export each one individually to Excel or PDF. While the visible report names suggest core LTC clinical data is exportable, significant product capabilities (detailed billing, CRM, admissions documents) appear absent from the export, and the documentation is too thin to assess completeness with confidence.

downloaded_files.description: The complete EHI export documentation page — a HubSpot-hosted instructional guide with embedded screenshots showing how to export data from ECP at company, location, and resident levels.
Full-page browser screenshot of the EHI documentation page, captured via Chrome DevTools.

Screenshot of Search Reporter field selection UI for Resident File Information, showing fields: First Name, Middle Initial, Last Name, Nickname, Suffix, Marital Status, Birthday, Gender, Race, Language, Religion, SSN, Medicare, Medicaid, Residency Start/End, Apartment Number, Phone, Task Rating, Hospital Preference, Funeral Home Pref, Pharmacy Preference, Pharmacy Phone, Code Status, Health Care POA, State Appointed Guardian, Guardian Name (partially cut off).

Screenshot of Vitals History report with date range selector and PDF/Excel export icons.
Screenshot of ECP home screen with Executive Menu highlighted.
Screenshot of ECP home screen with Admin Menu highlighted.
Screenshot of ECP home screen with a resident tile highlighted.

summary: ECP by Extended Care Professional, LLC is a specialty LTC/assisted living EHR with eMAR, care plans, billing, CRM, and admissions modules serving 8,000+ communities. Its EHI export documentation is among the thinnest encountered — a single instructional web page with screenshots showing how to manually navigate to various reports in the UI and export each one individually to Excel or PDF. There is no data dictionary, no schema documentation, no field definitions, and no bulk export mechanism. While the visible report names suggest core LTC clinical data (medications, diagnoses, vitals, assessments, care plans, incidents) is exportable, significant product capabilities — particularly detailed billing transactions, CRM/lead data, and admissions documents — appear absent from the export. The presence of an Audit Log is a positive finding, but the overall approach places full burden of completeness on the end user.
notes: The registered URL includes a HubSpot preview parameter (hs_preview=FslteQVE-143661230087), but the page also works at its canonical URL. The product has an unusually minimal ONC certification scope — only (b)(10) and supporting criteria, with no clinical (a), patient portal (e), or API (g)(7)-(g)(10) criteria certified despite the product being a full clinical EHR. This suggests a strategic decision to seek minimum certification rather than comprehensive certification. The Administration > Reports tab also shows tabs for 'Residents', 'Care Plan', 'Medications', 'Users', and 'System Settings', suggesting additional data categories that may be accessible but are not covered by the export documentation.
